It's a very exhausting place, being in fight mode all the time.“I’m kind of done, so I can actually start thinking about leaving… They’ve announced 450 job losses in News, I’m an expensive person - I should go.”The BBC’s outgoing director-general, Lord Hall of Birkenhead, and chairman, Sir David Clementi, have been summoned to appear before a Parliamentary committee next week.The Digital, Culture, Media and Sport select committee is “concerned” that the broadcaster is unprepared for this summer’s switch to charging over-75s for the licence fee.Julian Knight, the committee chairman, said: “The BBC has made headlines for the wrong reasons in recent months - axing hundreds of new posts, asking over-75s to pay up, and digging into budgets to settle equal pay claims.“Unprecedented changes in how we watch and listen mean the broadcaster faces a fight for its future. We are concerned about the BBC’s preparations to deal with these challenges, particularly when its director-general has decided to step down at such a critical time.”More from NewsMore from The We urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: coronavirus
story: One in five British workers could end up off work sick at the same time in the event of a major coronavirus outbreak, the Government's official action plan predicted yesterday.Faced with staff shortages, the police may be instructed to investigate only the most serious crimes and the NHS to treat only the sickest patients, the document stated.The Government contingency plan, unveiled by Boris Johnson, spelled out the measures Britain could be forced to take. The Prime Minister described the virus as a national challenge ... something that our country has to get through. The document detailed plans to help businesses threatened by the growing crisis and said that the Army was on standby to get involved in the crisis. The plan drew comparisons between coronavirus and the 1918 Spanish flu pandemic and revealed that the Government was working on a worst-case scenario of 500,000 deaths, with up to 80 per cent of the country becoming infected.The 28-page action plan stated that any major outbreak could be just the first of multiple waves to hit the country. The Prime Minister said the Government was committed to doing everything possible in order to limit the damage the virus could wreak on Britain, warning that it was now highly likely that it would continue to spread.The Government’s advisers said that if the outbreak became impossible to contain, they would expect it to take six to eight weeks to reach its peak.The worst pressures would likely be seen in April or May, while the fallout from an outbreak or pandemic could continue until August.The Government plan was based on estimates that the virus could infect up to 80 per cent of people, in a worst-case scenario. It suggested that at the peak of a crisis, this could mean one in five workers are off sick at the same time.Officials said they anticipated overall death rates of around 1 per cent, compared with death rates of around 0.026 per cent seen during the 2009 swine flu pandemic.But they were fearful of far higher death rates among the elderly, with research showing coronavirus has mortality rates of almost 15 per cent among those over the age of 80.The plan set out sweeping measures - including the use of police to maintain public order, and only fulfilling critical functions - that may be taken if a major outbreak or pandemic occurs.With a significant loss of officers and staff, the police would concentrate on responding to serious crimes and maintaining public order, said the document. It said the Army could be used to take over duties at protected locations such as nuclear sites, Parliament and Downing Street if police forces became understaffed due to illness.The Armed Forces were on standby to help fill gaps in vital public services if the pressures on them became significant and clearly noticeable.Meanwhile, border forces would be given police-style powers to detain people at borders if they were showing symptoms of the virus and refused to be tested.The action plan also pledged to ensure dignified treatment of all affected, including those who die. The document said the Government was ready to combat a severe prolonged pandemic as experienced in 1918 when Spanish flu killed up to 50 million people worldwide.Advisers said the profile of coronavirus was very different: far less severe for children and young people, but most deadly in the elderly. Care homes were advised to go into lockdown in the event of a major coronavirus outbreak, with visitors banned and sick patients confined to their bedrooms rather than being taken automatically to hospital.The guidance seen by The  came as health chiefs urged relatives not to go and visit your auntie in a care home” if they were suffering from a cold or flu-like symptoms. The plan spelled out the four phases - contain, delay, research and mitigate - behind the Government strategy.During the delay phase, which would be triggered when it became clear that it was no longer possible to contain the spread of the virus, actions could include school closures, encouraging greater home working, and reducing the number of large-scale gatherings.Yesterday, ministers repeatedly stressed that this stage had not yet been reached. Advisers warned that taking these steps at the wrong time risked creating an awful lot of disruption and could mean that people were unlikely to heed such advice when it became critical.Matt Hancock, the Health Secretary, said sick leave rules could be changed to allow people to sign themselves off work for two weeks in order to self-isolate. Mr Hancock told MPs the issue was under review, given that the current situation means a person must give their employer a doctor's note if they have been ill for more than seven days.Meanwhile, health chiefs in the Canary Islands confirmed the sixth person to test positive at the Tenerife hotel hit by coronavirus was a British woman who had been mixing with other guests for more than a week.A spokeswoman for the regional health authority admitted the unnamed Briton had not been confined to her room for most of her week-long stay at the four-star H10 Costa Adeje Palace.More from NewsMore from The We urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: governments coronavirus action plan detail
story: Boris Johnson set out his battle plan for tackling the coronavirus yesterday, promising that the Government will take all necessary and reasonable steps to beat it.The Prime Minister said he had no doubt at all that the UK is going to get through coronavirus and get through it in good shape.The 28-page coronavirus action plan outlines what the Government will do as and when it moves from the current strategy of containing the virus to the next stage: delaying its worst effects and then mitigating the problems when it peaks.Government health advisers suggested it is likely to take six months for the virus to run its course once it becomes impossible to contain, meaning it will be mid-August at the earliest before the outbreak is over.There is also the possibility of multiple waves of the virus if people are not immune to catching it more than once.The delay phase will kick in once health experts have advised that it is no longer possible to prevent widespread infections simply by isolating those known to have caught it.In the battle plan, and during a press conference yesterday, the Prime Minister and his senior health advisers set out how the NHS, police and other sectors would cope in the worst-case scenario, as outlined below.Soldiers will take over guard duties at protected locations such as nuclear sites, Parliament and Downing Street from the police officers who normally patrol them. Border Force officers will also be given police-style powers to detain people at borders if they are showing symptoms of the virus and refuse to be tested.And in the worst-case scenario, where workplaces could have up to a fifth of their staff off sick, understaffed police forces will be able to investigate only the most serious crimes.The Government’s coronavirus action plan also promised to ensure dignity for anyone who dies from contracting the virus, but it shied away from discussing the specifics for disposing of what could ultimately be hundreds of thousands of deaths in a worst-case scenario.Referring to staff shortages among police officers, the document said police and fire services will concentrate on fulfilling critical functions, adding: For example, with a significant loss of officers and staff, the police would concentrate on responding to serious crimes and maintaining public order.It also stated that the Ministry of Defence will provide support to civil authorities if requested.Government sources insisted that the Armed Forces would only take over guard duties at the most sensitive of sites. Unless you live near those sites, you wouldn’t be seeing the Army out on the streets, said one source.However, it is unclear whether soldiers could also be asked to take over patrol duties at mainline railway stations and other places usually covered by the police.NHS hospitals will be told to postpone anything postponable in the event of a major outbreak of coronavirus, England's Chief Medical Officer has warned.Routine operations would be cancelled, other treatments rationed and patients sent home from hospital early in a bid to free up beds for high-priority cases, according to the Government's coronavirus action plan. Health chiefs have declared the highest state of NHS emergency, ramping up efforts to cope with the crisis. All intensive care units have been ordered to carry out urgent checks on their patients amid concerns some could already be infected with the virus and at risk of spreading it among the most vulnerable.  A letter to NHS trust chief executives, seen by The , said that if the outbreak were to spread, all wards could be used to treat sufferers. The letter, from Professor Keith Willett, NHS Strategic Incident Director, stated: “It is essential that we detect cases admitted to intensive care at the earliest opportunity.” Until now, every patient with suspected coronavirus has been tested and treated in isolation. But, the letter warned, if the outbreak continued, every acute unit in the hospital would have be prepared to take such cases and make efforts to keep them away from other patients. The Government's coronavirus action plan said that if that were to occur, it would move to the mitigation phase of its strategy, which could mean significant and clearly noticeable pressures on services. Officials suggested this could mean routine NHS services being stopped for several weeks around the peak of an outbreak, which could start in six to eight weeks. Government sources said it could mean more than 50,000 operations being put on hold. Professor Chris Whitty, England’s chief medical officer, said that the NHS will be prepared to slow down or postpone anything that is postponable if it is facing a major surge in demand. The coronavirus action plan said: As NHS staff start to become affected, and more seriously ill patients require admission, clinicians may recommend a significantly different approach to admissions. Some non-urgent care may be delayed to prioritise and triage service delivery.It also stated that more will be done to support early discharge from hospital to free up as many beds as possible.Meanwhile, Dr Frank Atherton, the chief medical officer for Wales, said the UK was expecting a significant increase in cases next month.The best guess is then a period of six to eight weeks of quite significant levels of transmission in the UK, with a tapering perhaps in July and August - so an upsurge in April, possible peak in MayJune and a downturn later in the year, he said.Matt Hancock, the Health Secretary, said ministers were considering turning to private hospitals for extra bed capacity in the event of a major outbreak. He said it would be all hands to the pump in the NHS, with retired doctors and nurses, and volunteers, brought in to support healthcare services.While the action plan suggested around a fifth of workers across the UK could fall sick at any one time, the fear among officials was that the figure in the NHS could be far higher, given staff members' likely exposure to the virus. The Prime Minister, Boris Johnson, said the public could play its part by thinking about what we can to do to avoid too much pressure on the NHS when it comes to using services such as GPs and 111. He said: It will be quite important to be self-restraining where possible.  Sir Patrick Vallance, the Government's chief scientific adviser, said the crisis in the UK could last as long as six months, from the point that sustained person-to-person transmission is confirmed. So far the UK has seen 51 cases. Sir Patrick said: “You can think of it as roughly two to three months from an outbreak of sustained person-to-person transmission up to the peak - and two to three months after the peak to decline again is the timeline we would be thinking of.” But Prof Whitty suggested the biggest changes to the running of the NHS - such as  postponing operations - would likely last a number of weeks rather than months. More than six million people could end up off work when the coronavirus peaks, the Government has warned, in a major blow to businesses and the wider economy.The worst case scenario would take one-fifth of all employees out of the workforce, leaving a gaping hole in Britain's output as crucial workers are stuck at home or in hospital.Companies have been offered limited help to delay big tax bills, while workers may end up relying on the benefits system – particularly if they are self-employed.Boris Johnson, the Prime Minister, has said the Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy (BEIS) would be on hand to support companies to make sure they get through the short-term difficulties and make sure they have the protections they need. He added: We are taking each step as it comes.However, the help on offer to businesses facing slumping sales or a shortage of workers is limited, according to the coronavirus action plan.For businesses facing short-term cash flow issues (for example, as the result of subdued demand), an effective mitigation already exists in HMRC's Time To Pay system. This is offered on a case-by-case basis if a firm or inidual contacts HMRC about falling behind on their tax, the document says.This scheme lets companies pay the previous year's tax bill in instalments over time rather than in one go.Children's exams face being thrown into chaos if the coronavirus outbreak forces the Government to close schools.There are fears that any closures could coincide with the start of the GCSE and A-level exam season in May.The Government’s 28-page coronavirus action plan stated that, if the virus becomes established in the UK, action that would be considered could include population distancing strategies such as school closures … to slow the spread of the disease throughout the population”.It added: The UK governments' education departments' planning assumptions include the possibility of having to close educational settings in order to reduce the spread of infection.Ministers emphasised closures would be a last resort, but parents and teachers expressed anxiety on social media about the prospect of pupils' education being interrupted.Martin Clee, a science teacher from Holmfirth, West Yorkshire, added on Twitter: If Covid-19 goes big and mass school closures happened, say towards the end of Maybeginning of June, what happens to exam season?At least 10 schools are currently closed for deep cleaning following the return of either staff or pupils from one of the countries where the virus has taken hold. Around 19 more have only just reopened.Official advice was not to close schools but to isolate inidual pupils or teachers suspected to have contracted the virus before calling Public Health England.But there have been complaints about conflicting advice. Parents said they have been left confused by some schools sending pupils home to self-isolate while others shut altogether.The latest to shut was Hilbre High School in West Kirby, Wirral, which closed temporarily on Tuesday after a parent of a pupil tested positive for the virus. A deep-clean of the school will take place before it reopens.Some pupils at the school had recently returned from a skiing holiday to northern Italy, but headteacher Mark Bellamy said the case was not linked to the trip. In a letter to parents, he wrote: “Last week, I chose to keep the school open following advice from the Government and Public Health England.Today, as I believe this confirmed case directly impacts on my students and staff, I am closing the school.Whitehall sources said efforts were currently being focused on replacing teachers who had fallen ill by allowing colleagues from other schools to take their place or enabling children to travel to other schools.The Government could also relax class sizes beyond the maximum of 30 allowed in primary schools, allowing schools where one or more teacher is sick to send children elsewhere.Ministers are anxious to avoid widespread closures not only because it would disrupt children’s education but because it would place a wider strain on the workforce, with working parents forced to stay at home to look after their children.Government influenza pandemic preparedness strategies warned that school closures would place a significant pressure on health workers, handicapping their ability to come into work at a time when they are most needed.Teaching unions also expressed concerns over the prospect of an increase in class sizes, warning it could even make the risk of infection worse.Kevin Courtney, Joint General Secretary of the National Education Union, said: A cramped classroom will not keep pupils safe, potentially doing more harm than good, and arguably work directly against the 'social distancing' recommended in the action plan. It will not provide peace of mind for parents.Care homes have been advised to go into lockdown in the event of a major coronavirus outbreak, with visitors banned and sick patients confined to their bedrooms.Providers across the country have been issued with new guidance to prevent the virus from spreading among vulnerable and elderly residents, and health chiefs urged relatives not to go and visit your auntie in a care home if suffering from a cold or flu-like symptoms.At least two care homes in Britain have temporarily shut over concerns that residents may have come into contact with a confirmed coronavirus case. Death rates have shown that Covid-19 poses a far greater danger to the elderly and those suffering underlying health problems. Care homes are also feared to be at heightened risk because of the close living conditions.Professor Chris Whitty, the Government's chief medical officer, has said officials are keen not to take stringent measures, such as banning visitors from care homes at which no cases have been identified, too early because of the social cost involved.However, guidance issued by the Care Provider Alliance, the industry body representing adult social care providers in England, describes how care homes should go into effective lockdown if a resident is diagnosed with coronavirus.The Coronavirus Infection and Prevention Toolkit document says patients should be kept in their bedrooms rather than automatically being sent to hospital. If it is not possible to isolate people – for example, those who need dementia support or other specialist needs – symptomatic iniduals should be cared for in an area that can be separated from those who are unaffected, it adds.The guidance also advises care providers to consider restricting visits from all relatives until the outbreak is over and refuse to admit any new clients. It may be necessary to contact regular visitors and ask them not to visit the care setting during the outbreak of infection, it says.Care providers are also told to restrict the use of new agency staff in the event of a coronavirus case to lessen exposure to the disease.If this is unavoidable, block-book staff during the outbreak to limit the numbers of inidual agency staff potentially affected, the advice adds.  If staff are taken ill as a result of being exposed to the infection, you should follow national and local guidance on how to prevent the spread of the infection.Wales' chief medical officer, Dr Frank Atherton said: If you think about the most vulnerable populations, they are often in nursing homes or care homes. I think we need to intensify the advice to people that, if you have a cold or flu-like illness, don't go and visit your auntie in a care home.In the US, an outbreak of coronavirus in a nursing home near Seattle has left one resident dead and four others in hospital, three of them in critical condition. Of the home's 108 residents and 180 staff members, more than 50 have shown signs of possible Covid-19 infections, officials said.The Government's chief scientific and medical advisers have told holidaymakers to go abroad wherever they want – as long as they make sure their destination has decent healthcare.The advice follows the cancellation of hundreds of flights by airlines, with tourists and business travellers either scrapping travel plans or refusing to commit to bookings. Coronavirus has hit the airline industry particularly hard, with the value of the world's biggest airlines plunging by billions of pounds. Consumer groups warned that families who have booked to go on Easter holidays have been left confused in the wake of the outbreak, unsure over whether their trips are covered by insurance, whether it is safe to travel and whether flights will be cancelled anyway.One airline expert warned that the cost of some flights could rise, with routes scrapped to match dwindling demand.The chief advisers on the virus moved to clear up confusion over international travel at a news conference unveiling the Government's coronavirus action plan.Sir Patrick Vallance, the chief scientific adviser, said that the risks of travelling on holiday or for business are no greater than staying in the UK as soon as Covid-19 becomes widespread.Once the epidemic is everywhere, then actually restricting travel makes no difference at all, he said. At the moment we are certainly not recommending any change to behaviours in relation to that. If it grows in the UK, then of course it doesn't really make more sense to say that you're at more risk somewhere else than you are here.Professor Chris Whitty, the chief medical officer for England, advised people against travel to countries with a weaker health system than the NHS and suggested they choose a location based on the quality of treatment that would be available.If you happen to be in a place with a very weak health service at the peak of their epidemic, weaker than the NHS, that obviously might be more problematic – and this is particularly an issue for people who are older or have pre-existing health conditions, Prof Whitty said.The Coronavirus action plan says Foreign Office travel advice provides the necessary information for British nationals ... on what they need to know before deciding whether to travel and what to do if they are affected by an outbreak of Covid-19 while travelling.On Monday, both British Airways and Ryanair announced flight cuts, with BA dropping 432 flights between March 16 and March 28, and Ryanair cutting a quarter of flights to and from Italy between March 17 and April 8.But at a meeting of airline executives in Brussels on Monday, bosses warned of further economic damage to come. Willie Walsh, the chief executive of British Airways owner IAG, said there had been  a very significant fall-off in demand in Europe, especially in Italy, but predicted that it would stabilise in the coming weeks following a pattern seen in Asia.Emma Wiseman, a spokeswoman for flight comparison website Skyscanner, said a study of the cost of flights to 10 destinations from the UK for both February and June showed prices fluctuating with no obvious link to the virus spread.But Ms Wiseman warned of rises on routes where flights had been cut, including London to New York – which has seen flights in June rise by an average of 10 per cent. It's too early to say if recent events are likely to drive any permanent changes to flight pricing, she added.Martyn James, of consumer complaints service Resolver, said more customers were cancelling holidays because of illness or fears over coronavirus. He said customer complaints to travel firms using terms like flu had more than doubled in February compared to the same period last year.Rory Boland, the editor of Which? Travel, said: While the decision to cancel flights in the face of growing concerns around the spread of coronavirus may be understandable, passengers due to travel will want to know what this means for their plans, especially in the run-up to the Easter holidays.Given the circumstances, airlines should also consider offering flexibility to customers who don't want to travel, such as allowing refunds and waiving flight change fees for both existing and future bookings.The Government's action plan for dealing with coronavirus raises the prospect of major sporting and cultural events being cancelled in an attempt to stem the spread of the disease.The 28-page plan says population distancing strategies intended to reduce the risk of the virus spreading further could be implemented if the situation becomes worse.This may include reducing the number of large scale gatherings, raising the prospect that events such as the London Marathon, the Oxford and Cambridge Boat Race, football matches and music and arts festivals could be postponed.Matt Hancock, the Health Secretary, said on Tuesday that it was far too early to be able to tell whether the London Marathon would need to be cancelled, but did not rule it out if the virus became more widespread. The race is scheduled to take place in eight weeks, with one million spectators set to line the route. London Marathon Events said it was monitoring developments closely.At the same time, European football's governing body, UEFA, announced emergency working groups involving the Premier League and other governing bodies to cope with a potential fixture pile-up if matches are cancelled.The Premier League, Football Association and English Football League have discussed a worst-case scenario option of games being played behind closed doors if coronavirus spreads.Contingency options have been discussed by officials in the past week in case the Government orders a major shutdown of mass gatherings, as has been seen in Switzerland and France. It is understood the Premier League would consider playing matches in front of empty stands if it allowed the season to be completed.Inidual sports stars are increasingly likely to find themselves caught up in the crisis as the disease gains hold in the UK.England prop Mako Vunipola will miss the rest of the Six Nations after going into self-isolation over coronavirus fears, it emerged on Tuesday. A spokesperson for the England team said Vunipola had withdrawn from the squad after management discovered he had stopped over in Hong Kong, where there have been around 100 cases, on a flight back from Tonga at the weekend.A severe worsening of the coronavirus outbreak could also raise the prospect of the Grand National being cancelled. Thousands are set to flock to Aintree in April to watch the world's most famous horse race.More from NewsMore from The We urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: oxford college investigates feminist lecturer barred womens
story: An Oxford college has launched an investigation into a no platforming row, after a female historian was barred from a feminist event. Exeter College hosted an event to commemorate the 50th anniversary of Ruskin College's inaugural Women's Liberation Conference. Prof Selina Todd, an expert in the history of working-class women, had helped to organise the summit by enlisting the support of Oxford's history faculty, which provided facilitators and funding. She had been due to speak at the event, which took place on Saturday, but the evening before she was told that her invitation had been rescinded. The academic has been accused of being a transphobe for her involvement in women's rights advocacy and for her teaching of feminist history. Her research suggests women who posed as men in the past were often lesbians seeking to protect themselves or did so because they wanted to do jobs that were only available to men.Earlier this year, it emerged that she had been given security guards to accompany her to lectures after receiving threats from transgender activistsProf Todd, who was uninvited from the conference after other speakers threatened to withdraw if her speech went ahead, said she was shocked at her treatment.The row deepened when Prof John Watts, the chairman of Oxford's history faculty, also withdrew from the event in solidarity with Prof Todd. Now Exeter College has launched an investigation into the no platforming of Prof Todd, after a formal complaint was submitted by the journalist Toby Young on behalf of the Free Speech Union. Mr Young set up the organisation earlier this year as a way to counter censorship of lawful views. In a letter to Prof Sir Rick Trainor, the Rector of Exeter College, Mr Young pointed out that this was a clear breach of the college's own code of practice, which says all events held on college premises must ensure free speech is upheld. He also said it was in breach of its legal duty to uphold free speech. As far as I am aware, no one connected with the College made an effort to ensure Prof Todd's freedom of speech was protected, said Mr Young. The decision by the organisers to no-platform Prof Todd ... was particularly egregious given that she had helped get the conference put on.He added that when fellow speakers threatened to withdraw, the event's organisers should have told them that they would not be bullied into dropping Prof Todd. Sir Edward Leigh, the Tory MP for Gainsborough, has also written to the universities minister asking her to investigate. An Exeter College spokesman said it has received a complaint about the event which will be reviewed in accordance with our complaints and appeals procedures. Oxford's history faculty said it had been pleased to support the event, but added that it withdrew its support when Prof Todd's invitation to speak was rescinded. We cannot accept the exclusion of our respected colleague Prof Selina Todd from the event, and that means that we withdrew from the weekend’s celebration, a spokesman said. As an academic department, we simply cannot condone the no-platforming of people who hold and express lawful views. We believe it is always better to debate than to exclude: this seems to us a key principle of 1970, and we are sorry that the weekend's event took a different path.”An Exeter College spokesman said that it played no role in decisions about the event's programme or speakers. Exeter College is committed to the open and respectful discussion of ideas and to providing a supportive and inclusive environment in which the rights and dignity of all its staff and students are respected and valued, and in which people can work and study, without fear of discrimination or harassment, they added. More from NewsMore from The We urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: super tuesday 2020 live voting updates latest results bernie2
story: Joe Biden and Bernie Sanders will battle it out for the Democratic nominationBiden proves his strength with black voters in southern statesSanders leading California in early projections Bloomberg makes his last stand in Texas as he braces for a bad night Polls closed in California, the biggest prize of the nightWhich candidates are left in the race?Joe Biden had a strong start to 'Super Tuesday' with victories in key southern states, while Bernie Sanders has won his home state of Vermont and Colorado. Mr Biden took Arkansas, Tennessee, Alabama, Oklahoma and the battleground states of North Carolina and Virginia, but the two top prizes of the night - Texas and California - are yet to be declared.The results so far - particularly in Virginia and North Carolina - are a blow for Mike Bloomberg, the former New York mayor and billionaire, who poured more than $500 million of his personal fortune into TV advertising in Super Tuesday states.The two other candidates still in the race, Elizabeth Warren, the progressive senator from Massachusetts, and Tulsi Gabbard, the Hawaii congresswoman, are both also facing serious questions about their viability. What a gripping night this is shaping up to be. Bernie Sanders and Joe Biden appear to be neck and neck in Texas, the state with the second largest number of delegates available tonight. CNN polls show a margin of three points between the two candidates.Here's the demographic breakdown: Brad Parscale, Donald Trump's 2020 campaign manager, predicts tonight's results will end with a brokered convention, where no one candidate has enough delegates to win outright before the July event. In a statement, Mr Parscale said: “The results only increase the likelihood that no candidate will have enough delegates for a first ballot victory at their convention, which only means more chaos! The media is hyperventilating about Joe Biden but everyone should remember that he is just as terrible a candidate right now as he was a few days ago.At the same time, establishment Democrats have ganged up to try to deny Bernie Sanders the nomination, which is causing even more mayhem. Even if Bernie is not on November’s ballot, his big government socialist ideas will be because they have become mainstream in today’s Democrat Party. President Trump will wipe the floor with whatever Democrat is unlucky enough to be the nominee.”Polls have closed in delegate-rich California, with exit polls giving Bernie Sanders a 15-point lead in the state. If Mr Sanders maintains that lead, it will help him regain an edge on Joe Biden.There may be some tension in the Conway household tonight. George Conway, lawyer and husband to President Trump's senior aide Kellyanne Conway, has tweeted his support for Joe Biden. Mr Conway donated the maximum amount of $2,800 allowed for inidual donors to Mr Biden's campaign.Bernie Sanders' campaign requested an emergency injunction  asking for polls in Los Angeles County to stay open for an extra two hours after reports of delays and long lines in the Democratic primary vote.According to the request filed with Los Angeles County elections chief Dean Logan, multiple polling locations in the County have experienced extreme wait times for iniduals to vote, including wait times up to four hours to cast a ballot.Los Angeles County is one of several big jurisdictions in California that used new voting machines and procedures in the Super Tuesday primary.David Millward in Maine has this analysis on the New England results:It is no surprise that Bernie Sanders won Vermont. Things are looking interesting elsewhere in New England. There are signs that Elizabeth Warren is splitting the progressive vote. In her home state of Massachusetts, she is running in third place but has been backed by more than 20 per cent of voters.This is good news for Joe Biden, who has opened a seven per cent lead over over Mr Sanders.In Maine the result is on a knife edge where with nearly half the votes counted, Mr Sanders leads by just over 100 votes. Ms Warren has received nearly 15,000 votes, which could prove decisive.Joe Biden has won Massachusetts, which has 91 delegates at stake.Massachusetts was considered a must-win state for its home-state candidate, Massachusetts senator Elizabeth Warren, and election officials predicted high turnout. Nearly 230,000 voters took advantage of early voting last week, the first time the state has allowed early voting in a presidential primary.Ms Warren's viability in the race is now in serious doubt. Earlier today Mr Sanders' campaign refused to say whether Ms Warren should drop out of the race and endorse his campaign - something many progressive voters had urged - but it has cost Mr Sanders in some states. Meanwhile Mr Sanders has won the Utah primary, according to current projections. He won the state in 2016  against Hillary Clinton.Joe Biden hailed Super Tuesday as a good night that was getting even better as he addressed a crowd at his campaign HQ in Los Angeles, California. He has projected wins in seven states against three for Bernie Sanders. However the biggest prizes of the night - California and Texas - have yet to be declared.Jubilant Joe Biden takes selfies with supportersBen Riley-Smith, our US editor, watched the candidate working the line up close. Here's his report: Joe Biden was pumped up for his celebratory speech in Los Angeles, more energised than almost all of his campaign event stops in recent weeks. There's a reason they call it Super Tuesday! he said to a crowd of hundreds on a basketball court in the city - a rare outdoor event for a candidate. After the speech he headed to the audience, posing for selfies, giving hugs and shaking hands with jubilant supporters and, at one point, holding up a dog. One supporter had brought a giant Hope' Barack Obama poster, which he held aloft and repeatedly urge Mr Biden to sign. The supporter was, in the end, too far away to be heard.  Ed Hunsaker, who lives in LA and has been hoping for a Biden presidency for more than a decade, was watching on and said it had been a great night for the candidate.  Biden is a street-level guy. He knows what it means to try and get ahead, to get food on the table, Mr Hunsaker told The .  He gets that. He's never strayed from what he is.Paul Koretz, 64, who sits on the LA city council, was also looking on and said he did not predict this recent surge.  I have to admit a few days ago I did not see that coming. I'm a Biden supporter through and through and I would have been with him to the end.  I've been around politics for 50 years and I've never seen a sudden turnaround like this ever before. Biden hails &#34a great night&#34 in Los AngelesMr Biden's speech was briefly disrupted by a handful of female protesters who attempted to jump onto the stage with anti-dairy signs. The first woman to reach the raised platform the former US vice president was speaking from managed to clamber up, forcing him to stop speaking.  Amid the commotion a security guard managed to manhandle the protester off the stage after a couple of seconds, but then more people rushed froward.  What appeared to be Mr Biden's secret service detail - he continues to have one thanks to the eight years he spent in the White House - intervened.  The protesters appeared to be against big dairy. They were the same group who interrupted Elizabeth Warren, the Massachusetts senator, on Monday night during a speech in Los Angeles. Joe Biden has won Minnesota, Arkansas, according to exit polls in the state. Minnesota, which has 75 delegates up for grabs, is the home state of Amy Klobuchar, who suspended her campaign on Monday and endorsed the former Vice President. Bernie Sanders carried the state in 2016 and Ms Klobuchar's army of grass roots staff is being credited for Mr Biden's success in the state tonight.Meanwhile, Donald Trump is revelling in Mike Bloomberg's poor results.Bernie Sanders is taken the stage at a rally in his home state of Vermont, where he promises to win the Democratic nomination and defeat the “political establishment”.  You know, it's a funny thing, 31 years ago today we won the mayor race in Burlington, Vermont. And we won that race against all of the odds. Everybody said it couldn't be done. And when we began this race for the presidency, everybody said it couldn't be done. But tonight I tell you with absolute confidence, we are going to win the Democratic nomination. And we are going to defeat the most dangerous president in the history of the country, he told the crowd in Essex JunctionNick Allen has an update from Texas:With a third of the vote in Bernie Sanders is winning the showdown in Texas. But it's far from over. Mr Sanders had a lead of about five points - 28 per cent to 23 per cent - over a resurgent Joe Biden, less than had been expected.Voters cast ballots at the politan Multi-Service Center polling station in Houston, TexasInterestingly, Michael Bloomberg is competitive with 19 per cent. All those adverts must have gained some traction. The largest population centre in Texas is Harris County, which includes the rapidly growing city of Houston. Mr Sanders and Mr Biden are tied there, with Mr Bloomberg just behind. In Travis County, which includes the liberal city of Austin, Mr Sanders is running away with it, followed by Elizabeth Warren.Overall, it seems that Mr Sanders has done well in the early vote - one million Texans voted early - but less well on election day. Mr Bloomberg is doing better than expected, and that may have taken votes away from Mr Biden.Mike Bloomberg will reassess his campaign for the Democratic presidential nomination on Wednesday, according to NBC News.Here's a quick recap of the billionaire's spending in the Super Tuesday race:$224 million overall he spent on ads that ran in the 14 states voting today, according to data from Advertising AnalyticsOf that figure, $33.7 million went on TV, radio and digital adverts in Alabama, North Carolina, Vermont and Virginia, all of which have been called for his his opponentsJoe Biden is projected to have won Tennessee, but appears to have lost a few potential delegates to Mike Bloomberg. The state is a Republican strong hold and Democrats here tend to lean more towards the centre ground than in other states.  Exit polls project another win for Joe Biden - this time in Oklahoma, where the former vice president is currently around 12 points ahead of Bernie Sanders.The results appears to confirm Elizabeth Warren is having a very bad night. The Massachusetts senator grew up in Oklahoma and is struggling to cross the 15 per cent threshold required to win delegates.Mike Bloomberg is ignoring the Super Tuesday states, where he's faring poorly so far, and is focusing on the key swing state of Florida which votes on March 17. But reflecting the mood of the night, billionaire businessman left the stage after a lacklustre 10 minutes, in which he appeared to conceded he may not achieve the delegate wins he anticipated tonight. Bloomberg&#39s campaign are worried by the early resultsThe billionaire businessman told a crowd in West Palm Beach:  “As the results come in, here’s what is clear. No matter how many delegates we win tonight we’ve done something no-one else thought was possible. We’ve gone from one percent in the polls to being a contender for the Democratic presidential nomination.”Mr Bloomberg has spent $500 million of his own money on campaign advertising and his campaign are understandably worried by the results in North Carolina and Virginia. His candidacy is now in doubt. Bernie Sanders has won the Colorado primary. The Vermont senator had been expected to win the state, which has 67 delegates up for grabs.David Millward reports that Bernie Sanders' supporters remain buoyant despite Joe Biden's early leads.Mike Bloomberg is projected to have won the American Samoa primary. The US territory has a population of 57,000 and sends 10 delegates to the Democratic Convention.Mr Bloomberg was widely expected to win here - having hired seven full-time staff and advertising heavily on radio, TV and in the local press.It appears to be a bad night for Elizabeth Warren, who may suffer the embarrassment of losing her home state of Massachusetts. According to CNN's exit poll, the state is a toss up between Joe Biden, Bernie Sanders and the Massachusetts senator.Biden is projected to win a third state - Alabama, which has 52 delegates. All three states the former US vice president is projected to have won so far - Virginia, North Carolina and Alabama - have sizeable African American populations. If Mr Biden continues this success in the remaining southern states he may be able to offset any expected losses in California and Texas.Joe Biden is projected to score huge victories in Virginia and North Carolina and front-runner Bernie Sanders was expected to win his home state of Vermont, the first states to close their polls.A resurgent Biden has enjoyed a burst of momentum since a blowout win in South Carolina on Saturday, which led to endorsements from a flood of prominent party officials and former rivals.Key endorsements in Virginia include former governor Terry McAuliffe and Abigail Spanberger, a former CIA officer who managed an impressive victory in a Republican district in the state in 2018. This will stand Mr Biden in good stead in the state. It is a strong start for Joe BidenWith 14 per cent of the precincts reporting in Virginia, Mr Biden was winning more than half of the votes in that Southern swing state, well ahead of Mr Sanders, who was winning about a quarter of the vote.The former Vice President is also hoping to muscle aside Michael Bloomberg, the billionaire former New York City mayor, and consolidate support from moderates in Tuesday's voting, turning the race into a one-on-one contest against Mr Sanders.Sanders supporters cheer for early results at his rally in Essex Junction, VermontOpinion polls have shown Mr Biden gaining on Mr Sanders, a self-proclaimed democratic socialist, who hopes to take a huge step toward winning the nomination on Tuesday.Early exit polls by Edison Research showed Mr Biden was powered once again by strong support among African-American voters, winning more than six of every 10 in Virginia and North Carolina.In Virginia, Mr Biden also won the votes of more than four of 10 white college educated women, compared to about two in 10 each for Sanders and Elizabeth Warren.Joe Biden is projected to win Virginia, CBS News is reporting. Elizabeth Warren's campaign has just announced a string of campaign events for later this week, signalling the Massachusetts senator has no plans to drop out of the race anytime soon. Ms Warren is travelling to Michigan for a town hall event on Friday, followed by one in Phoenix, Arizona and Boise, Idaho on Saturday. Ben Riley-Smith has this from a polling station in a liberal part of the cityOne of Bernie Sanders's great advantages is the enthusiasm and energy he engenders in his supporters, who then take to the streets to help his cause.  There was a good example of this at a polling station in South Pasadena, an affluent bit of Los Angeles, where more than a thousand voters are expected.  With a few dozen people queueing outside a rather grand library under the clear blue sky to vote, there was a volunteer from only one campaign around. Her name was Linda Krausen, a 78-year-old retiree, and she is a big Bernie fan. She had Bernie earrings, a Bern necklace and light blue nail paint.  Every time a voter approached she went across to explain how the computer system worked, reminding them you have to press 'next' on the candidates page to find everyone on the ballot. She was handing out a single piece of paper, some in English and some in Spanish, that outlined Mr Sanders's pitch.  Bernie is the candidate whose platform most strongly supports working people of America, one line read.  Ms Krausen also said she had been up until 3am last night going round the area putting out Bernie flyers for people to see today.  She said one voter told her she was going to back Joe Biden but then saw a Bernie poster on her car this morning and decided to switch at the last minute. Times that activism by 2,000 - the number of people the Sanders campaign has on the ground across LA County, according to officials - and you get a sense of the scale of the Bernie ground game.  Who knows how big an impact all those volunteers could have? Nick Allen in Texas reports:   There have been reports of some Texan voters waiting up to two hours to cast their ballots.It seems to be a mixture of high turnout and technical problems at some polling stations.Voter Austin Black told local TV he waited two hours at a public library in Dallas.The Dallas County elections department said there were longer than usual wait times.Pictures emerged of a long line outside a polling station at a court building in Mansfield, and at a Dallas location three out of the four voting machines were not working.Powerful tornadoes tore through Nashville, Tennessee and surrounding counties early on Tuesday, killing at least 22 people, leaving others missing and reducing homes and businesses to rubble as voters throughout the state cast ballots in the Super Tuesday presidential primary.In addition to the fatalities, at least 30 people were injured and about 48 buildings were destroyed in Nashville, with many more damaged, Fire Department Director Chief William Swann said. Tens of thousands of people were left without power.Despite the destruction, polling sites were mostly open for voting, officials said.Crushed vehicles, piles of debris and broken power lines littered streets blocked by rescue vehicles. Residents carried away belongings from ravaged homes.Donald Trump said that he will go to Tennessee on Friday.Nick Allen is seeing high voter turnout in San Antonio.At the public library in San Antonio a steady stream of voters made their way to polling machines. By lunchtime 271 people had voted. Anecdotal evidence from election officials suggested that was high. It came despite about 10 per cent of voters casting their ballots early before Election Day. An election official told me voting is expected to be boosted by a recent rule change. Previously, voters had to vote at a specific assigned polling station. But this time they can vote at any location. “It means we’re getting a lot of people coming in on their lunch hour because they work downtown,” said the official. “In the past they wouldn’t have had time to go home to vote.“ She added: ”It does feel larger than last time, although it’s hard to tell for sure.” Facing voters for the first time, Mike Bloomberg believes the only way he can win the nomination is at a contested convention in the summer.Well, I don't think that I can win any other ways, he said according to NBC.A brokered convention will almost inevitably trigger accusations from Bernie Sanders’ supporters that the Vermont Senator will have been the victim of an establishment “stitch-up.Mr Bloomberg, however, has dismissed the idea rounding on Mr Sanders.There are rules in the Democratic Party of how you go about this. And I did see Bernie Sanders said all of a sudden, he didn't want to follow the rules ... I find it offensive that Bernie Sanders, who the last time he ran was in favour of that kind of a convention, and now was opposed to it. I guess where you stand depends on where you sit.Mr Bloomberg, who is being urged to clear the path for Joe Biden by following the example of Amy Klobuchar and Pete Buttigieg, is also showing no interest in pulling out of the race in which he has invested an estimated $500 million.Traders have been betting heavily on the Democratic race, according to Smarkets - a UK based prediction market platform. They have bet nearly $2.5 million on the outcome and the smart money seems to be going on Joe Biden, who has surged from eight per cent to 54 per cent to become the market favourite, overtaking Bernie Sanders who has slipped into second place at 35 per cent.Mike Bloomberg is trailing badly in third place at six per cent.But the bullish predictions for Mr Biden appear to have been undermined by the predictions for several of the key races, with the Vermont senator remaining favourite to win California, Texas and Massachusetts.There is growing speculation that California senator, Kamala Harris is set to endorse Joe Biden.Rumours have been circulating for a few weeks that she will throw her weight behind the former vice president.Now the gossip is that an endorsement is imminent.But few will forget how she skewered him in an early candidate’s debate over his record on race and his opposition to bussing, a policy which was used to desegregate schools“There was a little girl in California who was part of the second class to integrate her public schools, and she was bussed to school every day,” she said. “And that little girl was me.”Mr Biden was stunned by her remarks, accusing Ms Harris of a “mischaracterisation” of his position.Assuming the pair have patched up their differences, Ms Harris’s endorsement would be a huge boost for Mr Biden in California as he tries to head off Bernie Sanders in the delegate-rich state.Ben Riley-Smith, our US Editor, has this from a chat with a Bernie fanWhy does Donald Trump keep talking about Bernie Sanders being robbed of the Democratic nomination? A conversation with a Sanders fan in Los Angeles provides an insight. David Nesbitt is a 54-year-old software engineer. I found him leaning against a wall in a blue Bernie T-shirt on Sunday, having just seen the Sanders rally with more than 10,000 others. I asked about moderate dropouts. Pete Buttigieg had just quite the race out hours earlier. This was before he and two other presidential rivals endorsed Mr Biden on Monday. Key dates for the democratic hopefulsThe ‘they’ in this case appeared to be the Democratic Party establishment. The suggestion - moderate leaders believe Mr Sanders cannot win and were moving to stop his path. Then I asked Mr Nesbitt if he would vote for Mr Biden if he ended up as the nominee. There was a very long pause, perhaps more than six seconds, face scrunched in thought. “I might, I don’t know,” he eventually said. “We’ll see.” He said he would never vote for Mr Trump, but did pledge to back whichever Democrat is on the ballot. This happened to Mr Nesbit in 2016. Mr Sanders lost the primaries, Hillary Clinton won. He did not vote for Ms Clinton, picking Jill Stein, the Green Party instead.Scores of others did likewise. It is one of the factors Ms Clinton most often cites when she is asked about the reasons behind her shock defeat to Mr Trump in 2016. Mr Nesbit pointed out that it did not matter how he voted in California, which will always go Democrat. He is right. But in the swing states, this could be a massive factor. If Bernie loses and his army sits on its hands or votes for a third party candidate, either because they do not believe in or feel betrayed by the Democratic nominee, it helps Mr Trump. Which is why the US president is doing all he can to whip up aggrievment now. This just in from Ben Riley-SmithDonald Trump has accused Democratic moderates of trying to rig the presidential nomination race against Bernie Sanders after a string of last-minute endorsements for his rival. The US president attempted to pour fuel on the isions in the party as voters went to the polls in 14 different states yesterday to pick who they want to take on Mr Trump. Speaking at a rally in Charlotte, North Carolina, the night before voting, Mr Trump said: “It’s being rigged against Crazy Bernie. Crazy Bernie’s going to go crazy.”He accused Joe Biden, the former US vice president who was endorsed by three of his previous rivals in the race, of orchestrating an attempt to stop the Vermont senator.“They both supported Sleepy Joe. You know why? They made a deal,” Mr Trump told his supporters. On Twitter he wrote: “They are staging a coup against Bernie!”Nick Allen in Texas writes:Joe Biden and Beto O'Rourke chowed down at a Whataburger in Dallas last night. Whataburger is a Texan fast food institution and became synonymous with Mr O'Rourke's 2018 run for the US senate.Beto O&#39Rourke enjoys a &#34Whataburger&#34 with Joe BidenHe went to Whataburger a lot.. This is a first, said Mr O'Rourke, as he arrived with the former vice president in tow.Hey, folks. How are you? said Mr Biden. The two politicians then gladhanded the dozen customers inside before Mr Biden said: Let's get some food.Mr Biden ordered a Whataburger with cheese and tomato, fries and a vanilla milkshake, paying with cash. He then donned a Beto t-shirt and sat in a booth with Mr O'Rourke and his wife Amy, remarking on how good the milkshake was.As he tends to do Mr O'Rourke livestreamed the whole event, and it was widely watched across Texas.Ben Riley-Smith, our US Editor, has this from the West coastHello from Los Angeles where the sun is shining and the polls are open. California is the most consequential state voting today. Why? Because of the massive haul of delegates - the metric that will determine the winner - up for grabs. There are 415 delegates available here. That is more than a quarter of all the Super Tuesday total. In fact it is a tenth of the entire nationwide delegate pot.Bernie Sanders, if the polls are right - a big if in today's politics, admittedly - has a massive lead here. In the latest poll of polls from Real Clear Politics he is 12 points ahead. But Joe Biden is surging, doubling his vote share and vaulting Elizabeth Warren according to the same rolling poll average. He was at 11 per cent on Friday, now 23 per cent today. Mr Sanders was here on Sunday. He held a raucous rally where actor Dick Van Dyke, comedian Sarah Silverman and Chuck D, the rapper from Public Enemy, all appeared on stage. (Yes, really.)Van Dyke, 94, joked about concerns over the 78-year-old's age, saying he was probably getting married the day Mr Sanders was born. Chuck D urged Californians to get off the couch and vote. He also performed Fight the Power, fist raised. Mr Biden has picked California for a results night event - an interesting selection, given he is not expected to win here. His wife, Jill Biden, also has a campaign stop-off in the day. Ms Warren held an outdoor rally here on Monday evening in East Los Angeles, a part of the city where the vast majority of the population are Hiic or Latino. There were a lot of placards in Spanish, with some reading persiste - in reference to a Senate speech when a Republican tried to shut her down and complained she persisted.Chants of It's  time for a woman in the White House and dream big, fight hard rung out. At the end a van served churros with caramel sauce to the departing supporters. Whoever wins here today may well have a delegate lead in the overall race come Wednesday. Odds are that will be Mr Sanders. Nick Allen in Texas writes:Joe Biden gave a deeply personal speech last night when he accepted Pete Buttigieg's endorsement. And it is quite clear that Mr Buttigieg would play a big part in any future Biden administration.The two men appeared at a bar called The Foundry in Dallas, which is well known for its fried chicken. Mr Biden described how, during televised debates, he had looked across the stage at the young mayor and been reminded of his late son Beau.Perhaps that was why Mr Biden never attacked Mr Buttigieg during the debates. Mr Biden said: There hasn't been a harsh word between us since we started to compete.I don't think I've ever done this before, but he reminds me of my son Beau.I know that may not mean much to most people, but to me it's the highest compliment I can give a man or woman.Like Beau he has a backbone like a ramrod. I promise you, over the course of your lifetime, you're going to end up seeing a hell of a lot more of Pete than you are of me.Rozina Saburis on the ground in Fairfax County, Virginia. She writes: State officials are taking no chances in trying to avoid the sort of embarrassing glitches which turned  Iowa’s caucus into a shambles.Voter turnout appears to be lower so far today in Fairfax County, the county's director of elections, Gary Scott, tells me. In Virginia people vote in the mornings. Turnout is about 7 per cent right now,which is a little below what we’d expected, he says.Mr Scott says they have received a lot of questions about the coronavirus, but doesn't believe it's had any impact on voting day. There have been no cases recorded in Virginia, however there is one voter who requested an absentee ballot as he is currently in quarantine in Washington state, he adds.A little tidbit - Fairfax County is the only locality in Virginia which provides ballots in four languages - Spanish, Vietnamese, Korean and English. Here's what the ballot paper looks like:Fairfax county&#39s erse population means ballots are printed in four languagesPundits expect that pockets of the state like this, which are ethnically erse, will favour Bernie Sanders. But at a voting centre at Graham Road Elementary School, voters I spoke to appeared evenly split between Sanders, Biden and Bloomberg.One voter, Holly Griffiths, says she is hoping for a Sanders or Warren victory. Bloomberg is just a Democratic Trump to me. Biden was a great vice president but he had a great leader and I don’t really have a lot of faith in what he’s going to do, she tells me. We are leaning definitely towards Sanders because he’s been in politics a long time and he’s done a lot for civil rights and the LGBQT community, and this country is horrific for healthcare.Out in the Pacific, the American territory of American Samoa has a population of 57,000 and sends 10 delegates to the Democratic Convention.Something of a constitutional oddity, the population can vote in the presidential primaries but not the presidential election itself.Mr Bloomberg has hired seven full-time staff in Samoa and is also advertising heavily on radio, TV and in the local press.It looks to have paid off with Chief Fa’alagiga Nina Tua’au-Glaude announcing she is endorsing Mr Bloomberg.“He has my family's vote, and my village. That's why I am committing my time and effort to electing Mike president of the United States. He will bring integrity and honour to the White House.Mr Bloomberg’s senior adviser in Samoa, Karen Green, said he is fighting for every vote and delegate.“We are proud to have Chief Tua'au-Glaude's support and to have the largest ground game here in American Samoa before we caucus on Super Tuesday,” she said.“Mike's history of getting things done, and particularly his record of accomplishment in combating climate change, is moving voters our way.Having performed well in the early contests, the decision of Amy Klobuchar and Pete Buttigieg to suspend their campaigns raised a few eyebrows.It will probably have annoyed a number of voters who cast their ballot ahead of Super Tuesday to no avail.“Mayor Pete”, despite doing exceptionally well in Iowa and New Hampshire appeared to have plateaued and was hovering at around 11 per cent in national polling.Failing to make any impact among Latinos and African-Americans, it was clear that he faced an uphill battle to get above the 15 per cent threshold which is normally required to secure delegates at the national convention.Ms Klobuchar’s decision was also something of a surprise to her staffers, according to the New York Times. She gave no indication that she was pulling the plug on her campaign when she addressed a rally in Salt Lake City on Monday morning.With Bernie Sander’s juggernaut laying waste to much of the field, there was an air of panic among the Democratic establishment that the Vermont senator could prove unstoppable.Late last week John Delaney, a former Maryland congressman who was the first Democrat to announce he was running for the White House, penned an oped in the Washington Post urging other moderates to follow his example and end their campaign - thus paving the way for a single mainstream candidate.John Delaney urged moderates to unite behind one candidate“Everyone who enters the race for president has something to offer,” he wrote.“But only one person can win the nomination — the person who best answers the central question that voters are asking at that moment. And sometimes, even your best stuff is not good enough.”While not naming Bernie Sanders, Mr Delaney made it clear that mainstream candidates who stayed in the race risked splitting the moderate vote with devastating consequences.“But if they stay in, they must ask themselves: Will they continue to make a positive difference, or will they steer the race toward a candidate who either can’t win or can’t govern and, in so doing, undermine everything they care about?”Nick Allen in Texas writes:On Monday Texas celebrated its Independence Day - the day it split from Mexico in 1836. “This used to be Mexico,” voter Sylvia Mendez, 46, told me in San Antonio. “Candidates have to reach out.”By 2022 Hiic people will become the largest population group in Texas, and they are voting more too. A recent poll showed 64 per cent intended to vote in the next presidential election. Healthcare is the most important issue, and Bernie Sanders’ Medicare for All policy is proving popular.His Hiic supporters call him “Tio Bernie“ (Uncle Bernie) and “El Abuelito” (Grandpa). It’s going to be hard for other candidates to compete.Nick Allen in Texas writes:One might expect Democrats in Texas to be more conservative or moderate than those on the coasts. In 2016 Bernie Sanders got trounced in the state. Hillary Clinton got 65 per cent of the vote and Mr Sanders only 33 per cent.But something has changed. There has been a shift in the centre of gravity. A new Emerson College poll showed many of those who voted for Mrs Clinton four years ago are backing Mr Sanders this time.“What’s most interesting is watching Bernie Sanders competing in a state that he lost by 30 points just four years ago,” said Spencer Kimball, a professor involved in the poll.Another, slightly astonishing, CBS News poll showed 56 per cent of Democrat voters in Texas now view socialism positively, while only 37 per cent view capitalism positively.David Millward writes: Even though she abandoned her own bid for the White House, Amy Klobuchar emerged as one of the early stars of the campaign. Over the weekend she was darting around the country, taking in four states in one day rallying support.  Her barnstorming style and quick wit went down well with voters who turned out in ever-increasing numbers to hear her speak.She could prove a real asset for the former vice-president, especially in her native mid-west where the Democrats will need to regain voters who backed Donald Trump in 2016.Ms Klobuchar gave Mr Biden a resounding endorsement at a rally in Dallas on Monday night.“Joe Biden has dedicated his life to fighting for people,” Ms Klobuchar said, before introducing Biden at the rally in Dallas on Monday night.“Not for the rich and powerful, but for the mom, for the farmer, for the dreamer, for the veteran. He can bring our country together.”Nick Allen in Texas  writes:On the eve of Super Tuesday everyone seemed to turn up in the Lone Star state. Apart from the front runner Bernie Sanders. Joe Biden, who is hot on Mr Sanders’ heels, held his final rally in Dallas. Both Pete Buttigieg and Amy Klobuchar suspended their campaigns and erted to Texas to endorse him.A voter checks his phone before casting his ballot during the presidential primary in Houston, Texas On an extraordinary evening for Mr Biden he then got the backing of Beto O’Rourke (remember him?). Mr O’Rourke, like a returning contestant from a previous season, joined Mr Biden on stage and gave him a big hug. It was an endorsement that’s will carry some real weight in Texas.The polls - and there are many - have been all over the place, with one putting Mr Sanders 15 points ahead. But the latest has Mr Biden trailing by just five. The superbly timed endorsements could put him over the top.Rozina Sabur in Virginia writes:Virginia has 99 delegates up for grabs, the fourth largest of any state voting on Super Tuesday. Given the state's mix of economic and social ersity, a candidate's success here will be a good litmus test for how the rest of the country will vote. Hillary Clinton narrowly carried the state against Donald Trump in 2016, but Virginia will be an important state in determining the outcome of November's presidential election.The state's rural parts are deeply conservative but northern Virginia and university-educated women in the suburban areas contributed to the Republicans losing the House of Representatives in the 2018 midterm elections. Today's primary is expected to be a two horse race between Bernie Sanders and Joe Biden, with the urban, university areas expected to support the progressive senator and the suburban parts more likely to vote in favour of the former Vice President.Mike Bloomberg has also been competitive in recent polls and he has spent a lot of his money and time in the state.  A poll of polls shows Mr Biden and Mr Sanders averaging 29 per cent and 24 per cent respectively, with Mr Bloomberg on 14 per cent. Which candidate wins in Virginia may offer a clue of what is to come. Polls close between 7 pm and 8 pm local time, depending on the state. However most of the Super Tuesday states have some form of widespread early voting. Voters in Minnesota, for example, could start casting ballots in January. Millions of postal ballot papers went out to California voters on Feb. 3, the day of the Iowa caucuses.Number of delegates available in each stateBernie Sanders and Mike Bloomberg have had the widest and most aggressive footprint across the Super Tuesday states, largely because they've got the money to spend. Mr Bloomberg is advertising in all 14 states, while  Mr Sanders is on the airwaves in 12. It's the first time Mr Bloomberg will be on ballots after he skipped the first four voting states, making the day a critical test of his theory that he's the best candidate to stand against Mr Sanders and, later, Donald Trump.Mr Sanders spent Sunday in California, holding rallies in the state's major liberal strongholds. He's hoping his monthslong focus on the state and resonance with Latino voters will help him win a large chunk of the state's 415 delegates. Joe Biden also plans to be in the state today. He hopes his strong showing in South Carolina is a harbinger of coming success with black voters, who dominate the Democratic electorate in a handful of Super Tuesday states. Meanwhile Elizabeth Warren may suffer the embarrassment of losing the primary in her home state of Massachusetts to Mr Sanders. While Super Tuesday won't necessarily determine who wins the nomination, it has historically been difficult for a candidate who performs poorly on the day to recover. Here's a look at Tuesday's contests. As well as California and Texas, Arkansas, Alabama, Colorado, Maine, Minnesota, Massachusetts, Vermont, Utah, North Carolina, Virginia, Tennessee and Oklahoma are holding votes. The Super Tuesday states make up a erse range of voter groups. Most of the Southern states are Republican strongholds in the general election, while others like California are solidly Democratic. North Carolina is likely to be a battleground state in the general election.In California and Texas, white voters make up less than half the population. Hiics count for nearly 40 per cent of the populations in both states. California, meanwhile, has the nation's highest Asian population, at roughly 15 per cent. North Carolina, Tennessee, Virginia, Alabama and Arkansas have large populations of black voters, one of the Democratic Party's core voting blocs. The states blend a mix of urban and rural voters, as well as Democrats from all sides of the political spectrum. As candidates focus on wooing Southern Democrats in states like Texas and Arkansas, they must also be thinking about a message that can resonate in progressive San Francisco.Good afternoon and welcome to the 's live blog. Our reporters will be bringing you the latest from across the country as 14 states and one US territory cast their votes in the Democratic nomination contest. Super Tuesday is when roughly a third of Democratic voters will cast their vote in the party's presidential nomination, making it one of the most significant points in the race to take on Donald Trump. This year has added significance because California, the state with the most delegates, will also have its say on the same day.A candidate needs 1,990 delegates to become the party's nominee. California has 415 delegates available, followed by Texas which has 228 and North Carolina which has 110. In all, there are 1,357 delegates available today.The  values your comments but kindly requests all posts are on topic, constructive and respectful. title: joe biden owes super tuesday surge overwhelming support among
story: Joe Biden has won in Alabama, Arkansas, Massachusetts, Minnesota, North Carolina, Oklahoma, Tennessee, and VirginiaThree weeks ago, Joe Biden's campaign appeared to be on its last legs after his dismal fifth-place showing in New Hampshire's primary. His dominating performance tonight represents one of the most remarkable comebacks in presidential primary history.Two factors are responsible for Biden's resurgence: the strength of his support among African American voters, and a rush of endorsements from former rivals for the Democratic nomination and prominent party leaders.Biden's longstanding ties to South Carolina and his eight years as Barack Obama's vice-president helped bring him his big victory there on Saturday, as did a crucial late endorsement from Representative Jim Clyburn.Biden's South Carolina win clearly precipitated a shift in Democratic leaders' thinking about the race. Pete Buttigieg dropped out and endorsed Biden on Sunday, while Amy Klobuchar did the same on Monday. Biden was also endorsed by Beto O'Rourke, who ended his campaign months ago.State party leaders moved toward Biden as well. In Virginia, Biden racked up endorsements from Senator Tim Kaine, former senator John Warner, former governor Terry McAuliffe, and Representatives Bobby Scott and Don Beyer. In Texas, Biden won support from Representative Veronica Escobar, Mayor Steve Adler of Austin, and other state and local elected officials.Though Bernie Sanders is set to win California, there is little evidence that he is improving on his 2016 performanceThis late movement towards Biden clearly made an impact: so far, Biden has won the primaries in Alabama, Arkansas, Massachusetts, Minnesota, North Carolina, Oklahoma, Tennessee, and Virginia. Exit polls show that many Democratic voters made up their minds very late in the game: according to CNN, 49 per cent of Virginia's primary voters made up their minds in the past few days, for instance, and almost a third did the same in North Carolina. In Minnesota, 55 per cent decided in the last few days Biden's win there demonstrates the impact of Klobuchar's endorsement in her home state.African-American votes were key to many of Biden's victories.  In Alabama, 44 per cent of the Democratic primary electorate was black 72 per cent of these voters supported Biden. In Virginia, black voters comprised 27 per cent of the primary electorate, and 71 per cent of them supported Biden. He won 57 per cent of the black vote in North Carolina and 62 per cent in Tennessee.Though she remains bullish, this could be the end of the road for Elizabeth WarrenBut Biden also showed strength in states such as Minnesota and Oklahoma, where the electorate is overwhelmingly white and where Bernie Sanders defeated Hillary Clinton in 2016. Even in Sanders's home state of Vermont, Biden appears likely to clear the 15 per cent threshold to earn delegates in 2016, Sanders won all of Vermont's delegates. Sanders also won primaries in Utah and Colorado. But with four candidates meeting the threshold for delegates in Colorado, Sanders will not have the sort of edge he needs to make up for Biden's big wins elsewhere for that he must rely on an expected win in California. But that state's lengthy vote count means that we will not know how that translates into delegates for quite some time. In addition, Sanders's performance throughout the primary season has shown little indication that he is capable of delivering new voters in the sorts of numbers that might have made skittish Democratic leaders more open to him as their nominee. Instead, his support in 2020 appears to be about what it was four years ago. Nor has he shown much desire to expand his support to include other segments of the Democratic primary electorate.Meanwhile, Mike Bloomberg's attempt to do an end-run around the four early primary states and launch a candidacy on Super Tuesday has fizzled it appears that the former New York mayor has won only a handful of delegates, and won only in American Samoa's contest.Mike Bloomberg has spent a lot of money but only has victory in American Samoa to show for itSenator Elizabeth Warren of Massachusetts is trailing in her home state's primary but has shown little sign that she is considering ending her campaign.Even with results still to come from California, and with contests in Maine and Texas too close to call, this has been a remarkable night for Joe Biden and his campaign.Christopher J. Galdieri is Associate Professor at Saint Anselm College in New Hampshire and the author of Stranger in a Strange State: The Politics of Carpetbagging from Robert Kennedy to Scott Brown and Donald Trump and New Hampshire PoliticsThe  values your comments but kindly requests all posts are on topic, constructive and respectful.
